fields.descriptive_line: Sword and sheath dha the blade decorated with inlaid scenes, Burma, probably 19th century
fields.physical_description: Sword (dha) and Sheath; the hilt is of wood overlaid with lacquer and covered with silver sheet; near the blade it expands sharply is and is ringed with cord and bead design; in the centre is a broad area of niello work of silver monkeys and birds surrounded by foliage on a black ground; this is divided from the un ornamented area on each side by a border of bands and an undulating line; immediately below the pommel is a raised cord and bead band similar to the one on the bottom of the hilt; the pommel is also silver in pointed artichoke shape. The blade is of poor quality steel, single edged and tapers outwards slightly to within about 4 ins of the tip when it narrows to a point; for the top 5 ins of the reverse edge there is a design of an undulating line between two lines of inlaid gold on a black niello ground; this design is continued on each face near the reverse edge to within l in of the tip; on each face there is a central panel, which follows the outline of the blade, containing a design of figures and foliage and inscriptions in gold inlay on a black hatched ground. The inscriptions augment the scenes depicted in the design which illustrated the story of Mahaltambwa and Sulaltombwa; they read as follows: l. A saint is asking questions of Veda (arranging the wedding). 2. The marriage ceremony between Sulaltombwa and Veda. 3. Sulaltombwa, Mahaltombwa and the saint. 4. Sulaltombwa, Mahaltombwa and the giantess. 5 (Sulaltombwa and Mahaltombwa) were afflicted with blindness and were cured by the giantess. 6. Veda meets the two brothers Sulaltombwa and Mahaltombwa. The sheath is of plain wood, the two halves being held together with copper wire. [Sword] Sword dha, the hilt is of wood overlaid with lac and covered with silver sheet; near the blade it expands sharply and is ringed with cord-and-bead design; in the centre is a broad area of niello work of silver monkeys and birds surrounded by foliage on a black ground; this is divided from the plain area on each side by a border of bands and an undulating line; immediately below the pommel is a raised cord-and-bead band similar to the one on the bottom of the hilt; the pommel is also of silver in pointed artichoke shape. The blade is of poor quality steel, single edged and tapers outwards slightly to within about 4 inches of the tip where it narrows to a point; for the top 5 inches of the reverse edge there is a design reverse edgea of an undulating line between two lines of inlaid gold on a black niello ground; this design is continued on each face near the reverse edge to within 1 inch of the tip; on each face there is a central panel, which follows the outline of the blade, containing a design of figures and foliage and inscriptions in gold inlay on a black hatched ground. The inscriptions augment the scenes depicted which illustrate the story of Mahaltombwa and Sulaltombwa; they read as follows:- 1. A saint is asking questions of Veda (arranging the wedding). 2. The marriage ceremony between Sulaltombwa and Veda. 3. Sulaltombwa, Mahaltombwa and the saint. 4. Sulaltombwa, Mahaltombwa and the giantess. 5. (Sulaltombwa and Mahaltombwa) were afflicted with blindness and were cured by the giantess. 6. Veda meets the two brothers Sulaltombwa and Mahaltombwa. [Sword sheath] The sheath is of plain wood, the two halves being held together with copper wire.

fields.materials_techniques: Silver, niello work, wood, lacquer, gold.

fields.name: South and South East Asian Collection

fields.bibliography: A similar weapon is illustrated in Holstein II, pl. XXXV no. 184 and described on pp. 107 as Siamese. Egerton "Indian & Oriental Armour" pp.84 no. 241
fields.credit: Given by The Rt. Hon. Earl Kitchener
fields.history_note: Given by the Right Hon. the Earl Kitchener of Khartoum
